unnormalised: Okay, so exams are looming, like Diwali relatives asking about your marks. And everyone's suddenly singing the praises of exam prep apps. But are they *actually* helpful, or just another distraction?
normalised: Okay, so exams are looming, like D-i-w-a-l-i relatives asking about your marks. And everyone's suddenly singing the praises of exam prep apps. But are they actually helpful, or just another distraction?

unnormalised: I've been down that rabbit hole myself, prepping for the JEE last year. There are tons out there – from the big names like BYJU's and Vedantu, to smaller, more specialized apps. I found some really useful ones for practicing MCQs, especially for subjects like Physics. Being able to do a quick 15-minute practice session at 3:00 PM on my commute from coaching in Kota was a lifesaver.
normalised: I've been down that rabbit hole myself, prepping for the J-E-E last year. There are tons out there – from the big names like B-Y-J-U's and V-e-d-a-n-t-u, to smaller, more specialized apps. I found some really useful ones for practicing M-C-Q-s, especially for subjects like Physics. Being able to do a quick fifteen minute practice session at three zero zero P-M on my commute from coaching in K-o-t-a was a lifesaver.

unnormalised: However, the biggest issue I faced was falling into the trap of endlessly browsing through lectures and 'motivational' content instead of actually studying. It felt productive, but my scores weren't reflecting that!
normalised: However, the biggest issue I faced was falling into the trap of endlessly browsing through lectures and 'motivational' content instead of actually studying. It felt productive, but my scores weren't reflecting that!

unnormalised: Honestly, I think the key is moderation. Use apps strategically. Maybe dedicate, say, 1 hour a day. Use the mock tests religiously – that's where the real value lies. And don't forget your good old NCERT textbooks! Also, remember that sometimes the offline methods still work better like sitting with Sharma uncle's nephew who cleared the IAS in 2018 with flying colors.
normalised: Honestly, I think the key is moderation. Use apps strategically. Maybe dedicate, say, one hour a day. Use the mock tests religiously – that's where the real value lies. And don't forget your good old N-C-E-R-T textbooks! Also, remember that sometimes the offline methods still work better like sitting with S-h-a-r-m-a uncle's nephew who cleared the I-A-S in two thousand and eighteen with flying colors.
